intro: Valeriana hispida, commonly known as rough valerian, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to parts of Europe and Asia. It typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and features opposite, lance-shaped leaves that are covered in fine, stiff hairs. The plant produces small, pale pink to white flowers arranged in dense, cylindrical clusters called spike-like inflorescences. Its roots are often harvested for their aromatic properties and traditional medicinal uses. Valeriana hispida thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodland edges and meadows.
